hold up.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to support something and prevent it from falling down
hold up.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The roof is held up by massive stone pillars.
hold up.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Sorry I’m late – I was held up at work.
hold up.translation[0].definitions[1].no: Hold up is often passive in this meaning
hold up.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to rob or try to rob a place or person by using violence
hold up.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Two armed men held up a downtown liquor store last night.
hold up.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: His physical condition has held up well.
hold up.translation[1].definitions[0].de: a situation that stops something from happening or making progress
hold up.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Despite the odd hold-up, we finished on time.
hold up.translation[1].definitions[1].de: an attempt to rob a place or person by threatening them with a weapon
hold up.translation[2].definitions[0].de: if a price, value etc holds up, it stays at or near the same level, especially when it was expected to fall
hold up.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: Copper prices held up surprisingly well during the recession.
hold up.translation[3].definitions[0].de: a delay, for example in transport or production
